text:
Last time, we started talking
about the most general type

of FMCW radar, which
is the MIMO radar.

That's the case where you have
multiple transmitter antennas, multiple receiver antennas. And then it enables you to--

this antenna
diversity, basically, enables you to determine the
direction of arrival of targets

with some clever DSP. So we started by introducing
this idea of the visual antenna

array. And this is a purely
mathematical construction. Basically, if you have
a MIMO array, which

has N-sub-Tx transmit antennas
and N-sub-RX receive antennas,

so physically you only have
NTx plus NRx antenna elements.

But mathematically, we
showed that it is equivalent. And by mathematically
equivalent, I mean essentially
the signal that you

receive from it is equivalent
to a SIMO array, Single

Input, Multi Output where
you have just one transmitter and you have P
receivers, where P

is equal to the
number of transmitters times the number of receivers
in the original antenna array.

And then the way this virtual
antenna is constructed, well, it's important to know
where these visual elements are

placed, what are the
locations of them. The transmitter, you can
assume it's at the origin,

it's at zero. And then the positions of the P
receiver antennas, each of them

is the sum of the
positions of one of the original
transmitters, plus one of the original receivers.

So the indexing is K for
original transmitter antennas, Q for original
receiver antennas,

and then P for the
virtual receiver antennas. And then the tilde also, is
so that when we talk about--

sorry-- the prime,
the R tilde prime, that's the position of the--

actually, is my notation
inconsistent with the notes? I think I should
remove the tilde here

to be consistent with
the lecture notes, maybe something like this.

So the tilde is for
the virtual array. Yeah, you can cross-check. But the point is now we can
basically do all of our DSP

in the individual-- n in the signal model that we
define on the virtual array.

So the way it looks
like is, let's say physically you have
a 2 by 3 MIMO array,

so the two triangles show
there are two transmitters, and the three diagonal
circles are the positions

of the three receivers. So if you look,
say, on your PCB, these are the
positions that you see.

So physically, you have only
five antennas, 2 plus 3. But the virtual array
would have six antennas--

six receiver antennas, which
have shown by the squares here, and then there's
two diagonal rows.

How did I get this? Again, from here, you
just add the positions of the transmitters
and the receivers,

and then you get that shape
for the virtual array. And then we showed that for
the virtual array, basically

the full signal
model we can work with for the entire end-to-end
DSP pipeline is given by this.

So the IF signal, so the
signal after down conversion, that you receive from virtual
antenna receiver number index P

is equal to this
summation, I from 1 to K. This is to account for receiving
echos from multiple targets.

So say, there's big K targets,
all simultaneously echoing back, so we are
summing the signals

received from all of them. That's just a
superposition principle. So that's why
there's a sum here.

And then the signal
from each target, it has what we call a
spatial phase term, which

is this E to the J, big
omega PI, P for the index, again for the visual
antenna, I for the target.

That's why there's
double indexing here. And this term, I call
it the spatial phase

because there's no
temporal aspect to it. It's just affected
by the direction

of arrival of the echos. And then there is the temporal
part, which is the SIFI of T.

And this one, as you see,
it has time dependence, but it does not
have P dependence.

So it doesn't matter which
virtual antenna you look at. They all-- the
waveform they receive,

the temporal part of it or
the time dependency of it is the same. The part that is different
between different receiver

antennas is this,
the spatial part. And that's why we
focus on this term when it comes to direction
of arrival estimation.

Specifically, this
face stem, omega PI is given by this formula, which
is basically your wave number

minus-- or minus the wave
number, 2pi over lambda, times the norm of the position
of the virtual element,

of virtual antenna P, times sine
of theta I. Essentially, what we want at the end of
the day is this theta I,

because that's the direction
of arrival of the target. So if you look at
this, if you want

to develop DSP algorithms that
estimate basically theta I

for you for DOA, it's
important to know-- basically,

your algorithm needs to
know what this term is, what the norm of the position
of the antenna elements are.

So the geometry
basically matters. And geometry-- by geometry,
I mean these positions. So here, in this case, like the
fact that they're positioned

diagonally, that also affects
the phases that you receive in addition to the
theta I. So from this,

you can see that by changing
the positions of the elements,

it can affect the performance
of your DOA, basically. And we'll see exactly
how it affects it today.

But to develop our,
basically, algorithms, we went with the simplest
geometry that you can think of,

which is a uniform linear array. Basically, this
here, for instance, is not a uniform linear array.

A uniform linear array, all your
visual elements are on a line, and they are equally spaced.

So if I were to draw a
ULA, basically all elements are like this. And the spacing, we call that D.
So every two are spaced D apart

and they are on a line. And that's a ULA. So, again it's the simplest,
simplest array geometry

you can think of. And then we developed
the DSP for that, and we showed that to
find theta I for ULA,

you basically can just do
another Fourier transform. From the signal
model, we simplified

it and we showed that another
Fourier transform, basically you can recover this theta I.

So here is, on
the slide, the end

to end DSP for a
MIMO FMCW radar.

Let's trace it again together. So this is essentially
everything we talked about, not just DOA--

range estimation,
velocity estimation, target detection,
and DOA, all the way

to-- so from raw signals that
you receive from the ADC, ADC samples, to the final
image, which is, say,

a point cloud, a 2D
or a 3D point cloud. So you start with these-- excuse me-- these IF
signals, SIF1 to SIFP,

so these are coming from
the visual elements. Or the other way you can think
about it is each of these SIFs

is coming from a combination
of a transmit antenna and a receiver antenna.

So transmit number one
transmitted, receiver number one received, transmit
number one transmitted, receiver number two received.

So all those combinations,
you put them-- or you collect them
together and that's

what we call a raw data frame. So you have three indices. You have your virtual
antenna index, that's

P. You have, of course, your ADC
sample index, that we call N. And we know we use
multiple chirps in a frame,

so you have your chirp index
inside the frame, and that's M. So basically, the data format
that we work with, it's a cube.

So you can populate them in
a M by N by P raw data cube. And then you can start,
basically, processing it.

The way the processing is
done, typically first you arrange in Doppler processing.

So you can think of them as
two basically individual FFTs,

or you can combine them as a
single two-dimensional FFT. Here we have shown them
as independent FFTs.

Again, mathematically
it's equivalent. You can decide how
you like to do it. But you do an endpoint FFT
along the, basically, ADC

sample index, or the
axis, or the N axis. So that's your range,
basically, are along the rows

here, that's your
range FFT, endpoint. And then you do your
Doppler processing,

that's an endpoint
FFT along the columns. And, again, you have to
do it for every slice.

Again, I'm just showing
these for the first slice, but after you're
done with that, you go through your second slice
or second virtual antenna

and do the same. So for that, you do across rows. That gives you your
range processing.

And you go across
the columns of it to do your Doppler processing. So you should go through the
entire cube, all the slices.

So after that, you're basically
done with range and Doppler processing. You can do target detection
with fixed thresholding or a 2D

CFAR. So what that does for you,
it basically chooses range

and Doppler indices
that we think contains an actual target. And everything else, you can
assume there's nothing there.

It's just-- it's just noise. So that's what we call
L hat I and K hat I. So those Are actual targets.

And then for those L
hat I and K hat I-- so if I cleaned
this a little bit.

So let's say, just pick-- let's pick just one
of those combinations.

So let's say this cell
here is one of those that contains a target.

So, of course,
after processing, so this is one of those L
hat I, K hat I indices.

And then you go-- for your DOA processing,
you basically

go through the third dimension. So you go basically in across
all virtual antenna elements.

So that becomes a
vector of length P that then you do an FFT on.

And then that FFT essentially
converts the virtual antenna index to a DOA index
Q that we can then

map to actual angles with
a simple transformation that we talked about.

So that's your DOA processing. There's the third
FFT essentially.

And then on that, you
want to also detect, after you do that FFT, the third
FFT, you look at its amplitude,

and then you pick the
indices that are basically above a threshold. It could be a CFAR threshold
or a fixed threshold.

That gives you
basically the Q hat I's, which are indices
for the DOAs of where you

think the actual targets are. And finally, so
at this point you have basically three indices,
one for Doppler, one for range,

and one for DOA. So these are
indices, and then you can map them to physical
quantities, which

is velocity in meters per
second, range in meters, and DOA in degrees or radians.

And that conversion,
it's just basically like linear transformations,
except for DOA, which involves

a arcsine transform, as we saw. And by this point, basically
this is the end of your DSP.

So you have detected your
targets, and for each target you know the range, you know the
velocity, you know the angle.

And then you can
decide how you want to essentially
visualize or represent

this fully processed data. A common way is to
generate a point cloud.

So a point cloud, you basically
use the range and the angles of the targets, and put a point
for every target in the 3D

space, and generate
a 3D point cloud. Or a 2D point cloud, if you
only have, say, azimuth angle.

Then you make like a bird's
eye view to the point cloud. Sometimes, I've seen
that velocity is also

used in the visualization, a
very interesting common way is use velocity to assign colors
to the points in the point

cloud. Like things that are
moving, you can show them in a different color. It just makes a more
interesting, richer

representation. OK, any questions about
this, the DSP of FMCW MIMO?

OK, and one thing to
note is, again, there

is different variations of it. This is-- most of this is
like standard vanilla DSP,

but you would see
different variations of it. Another common one is, you
can see in the literature,

that sometimes this target
detection step, the 2D CFAR is omitted, and you
basically feed everything

into your DOA processing. That's fine, it still works. And then after that
instead, of a 1D CFAR,

you do a 3D CFAR cross
range, Doppler, and DOA, and in one shot detect
where the targets are.

And then if you do
that, you can basically combine range processing,
Doppler processing, and DOA processing into one 3D FFT.

The point is, it wouldn't
be very efficient. Because you would do a lot of
FFTs where there is no target.

So the reason I
like this better is that you make it more
efficient by filtering out

a lot of the data at this
step, with the 2D CFAR, and then for DOA only,
basically, focus on where

you think the targets are. But again, the point is,
there is variations of it. Also, as usual, very
important to always remember

the assumptions that went
into every step of the DSP.

So specifically, for
instance, for the DOA we made a bunch of assumptions,
like the fact that you can do a FFT, it's
correct only if you

have a uniform linear array. If your array is a
different type of an array, then this algorithm
wouldn't work for it.

And you have to rethink or find
another algorithm that works.

OK, questions? All right, so one thing
we haven't looked at is from our DOA algorithm,
this FFT algorithm,

what resolution we
can expect and what is the maximum field
of view that we get.

So those are the two things. Exactly like the thing we
did for range and velocity

processing, that after we
developed the algorithm, we looked at the resolution and
the maximum range and velocity

that we can get, we're
going to do the same for this digital
beamforming algorithm

that we developed using FFTs. So the way-- let's look
at resolution first.

So let's look at basically
two adjacent DOA angles

that our algorithm
can discriminate, call them theta Q
and theta Q plus 1. So those correspond to two
adjacent FFT bins, basically.

That's like the
minimum angle you can discriminate with an FFT. So let's take the
average of the two.

So theta Q plus theta
Q plus 1 over 2, that's the average of the angles
corresponding to those two FFT

bins. Call that theta. And that's like our
angle of interest. So we want to see,
at that angle, what

is the resolution to expect? And then the actual
DOA resolution would be the difference between
theta Q and theta Q plus 1.

so. That's just the delta. As you shift 1 FFT bin,
how much the angle changes. So we want to find
this delta theta.

That's our DOA resolution. So we know that
there is a nonlinear

mapping between the actual
angle and the FFT frequencies.

So if you remember, we defined
this parameter, F sub theta, which was equal to 1
over lambda sine theta,

or make it more
concrete, so F theta I was 1 over lambda sine
theta I. And from the FFT,

we actually find
these frequencies, and then we apply
the inverse transform to find the angles
from the frequencies.

So there was this sine
inverse transformation. So using that, the sine of
theta Q minus the sine of theta

Q plus 1, that would be equal
to lambda times delta F theta. So delta F theta is
actually the width

of one FFT bin, which as you
know is equal to the sampling rate, F double prime S, divided
by the total number of points

in the FFT, divided by P. And
it's just a scale by lambda. And the sampling
rate, if you remember,

for a ULA, Uniform
Linear Array, was just equal to F double
prime S, was just one

over D, where D is the spacing
between the antenna elements. So every two adjacent antennas
were basically a distance D

apart. So then sine theta
Q minus sine theta Q plus 1 becomes equal to
lambda divided by P times D.

What is big P total number of
virtual elements in the array? D is the spacing between them.

OK, so-- but we want
to find delta theta. We just apply a
little geometric--

sorry-- trigonometric identity. Remember, we have
this identity, which is sine alpha minus
sine beta, equals

this, which is 2
times the cosine of alpha plus beta
over 2, times sine of alpha minus beta over 2.

Apply this to this expression
up here, and the left-hand side becomes equal to 2
cosine theta times

sine of delta theta over 2. And the left-hand side,
we haven't touched.

It's lambda over PD. So at this point, we
are pretty much done. We just make the assumption
that delta theta is a small--

it's the resolution
of our radar. And if it's a good resolution,
that angle is a small.

So for a small delta theta,
you can approximate sine of delta theta over 2 by just
the angle itself in radians--

delta theta over 2. So use that. So plug that in
here, and then we

can solve for delta theta,
which is the resolution we want to find. It just becomes equal to
lambda over P times D,

times cosine theta. So this is-- this delta theta,
this is the DOA resolution that

we can get from
our FFT algorithm, again for a uniform--

uniform linear array. Very important, this is not
true for any arbitrary array.

But this is very insightful. We did a bunch of
math, but it's always what's behind the math that is
interesting, and insightful,

and important, which is,
if you look at this-- so we want delta
theta to be small. We want good resolution,
meaning small delta theta.

But here's the first observation
that is very interesting. Delta theta has this
cosine theta term

in the denominator, which means
that the DOA resolution is not uniform across the field
of view of your radar.

If you look down boresight,
that's where theta is zero, cosine theta would be one, so
you get best resolution there.

But as you go to larger
angles on either side-- so as you go towards the
edges of the field of view

of your radar, this
cosine theta term drops. Large theta, cosine theta,
becomes a small, which

means delta becomes large. So you have worse
resolution towards the edges of your field of view
and better resolution

in the middle, down
boresight-- very important. So it's non uniform
DOA resolution.

That's insight number one. Number two is what can we
do design wise to improve
the resolution of our radar? Well, lambda is lambda. It's-- it is what it is.

I mean, of course, smaller
lambda, which means higher frequencies, helps. We know that's always the case.

Higher frequencies, better
resolution, and that's true in optics. That's true in
millimeter wave radar. That's true in acoustics,
sonar, and so on.

That's one of those general
physics principles, that higher

resolution-- higher
frequency, better resolution. So that's one. But for the case of radar, you
don't have much of a choice.

If you're working
at 77 gigahertz, there's a little bit
that you can vary lambda.

But you would have a lot of
flexibility in choosing P and D. P is the total
number of antennas.

And D is the spacing
between them. So P times D is what we call
your total aperture size.

It's technically P minus 1
times D, but let's call it-- P's large enough, so
that's your aperture size.

And what I mean by
aperture size is, again, if you look at your
virtual antenna array,

you have element one
element two, all the way to the last one. So that's like our
RX1 to RX number P.

And the total aperture size
is basically the entire span, like that distance that you're
end to end-- your first element

and your last element,
how far apart they are, that's basically how big
your full aperture-- antenna

aperture is. And bigger aperture,
better resolution. Again, the exact same thing as
we saw in sonar, for instance.

In sonar, when we were talking
about transducers, if you remember, we said bigger-- bigger transducer aperture size
means more focus, more narrow
beams, better DOA resolution. Same for radar. This is also true in optics.

For instance, in
photography, if you've seen professional
photographers have lenses with huge apertures, that's
because that gives you

better resolution. Again, same tradeoff at
a different wavelength.

But here, we see the version
in basically radio frequencies.

So summarize, non
uniform resolution across the field of view,
better at small angles,

meaning down boresight,
worse at larger angles. And also, to improve
your DOA resolution,

you need arrays with
bigger apertures, either more elements or
space them further apart--

bigger aperture,
better resolution. I have a question. Yes. [INAUDIBLE] but can you
say a little bit more
about what FS double prime is? Yes, so FS double prime here--

the question is
what is this term. So this is essentially
the sampling rate

of our signal across
the antenna dimension. So if I go back where we
were on the DSP slide.

OK, so if you look at
this, basically, data cube,

if you look at the three
axes, across each axis there is a sampling rate.

So horizontally, the sampling
rate is your ADC sampling rate. That's your N index. And then if you go
down the columns,

what we call the slow
time, the sampling rate is the time between
chirps, so when

you have multiple
chirps in a frame. And then if you go across
the virtual antennas,

the sampling rate
is that FF double prime S, which is dictated
by the physical spacing

of your antennas. So it's like the
spatial sampling rate, instead of a temporal
sampling rate.

Another way to
think about it is-- let me try to sketch it maybe
on this slide that we were.

So if you have-- if
these are the elements

of your virtual array
that are distance D apart,

and then if you have
some incoming echo wave at some angle from a
target, essentially what

these antennas give
you, they're going to sample the phase
of this wavefront

at positions that are D apart. So it's this F double prime
S, which is equal to 1 over D,

is the spatial sampling
rate of your antenna array for the incoming
echo, basically.

That's how far apart
you sample the phase of that incoming wave.

And it has-- it
matters because we are trying to estimate that phase.

So for instance, if you
don't sample it fine enough, you could not find
very high frequencies.

So you can see D
should matter when it comes to the field
of view of your radar.

If D's too large, that means
you're sampling too coarsely. So you cannot find high
frequencies in your FFT,

which means large angles-- angle of arrivals cannot
be determined, basically.

But back to your question. F double prime is
basically the sampling rate along the antenna axis.

It's a spatial sampling
rate, not a temporal. It's a spatial sampling
rate across the antennas.

OK, so that's about
the DOA resolution.

So, again, to improve
the resolution, you need to increase the
virtual aperture size.

We call that A,
which is equal to P times the total
number of antennas, times the spacing, which is the
total aperture size, basically.

What about the maximum
detectable-- maximum unambiguously detectable DOA?

And that's basically
the field of view. What is the maximum angle
that you can detect? That, exactly like the case of
range and Doppler processing,

is determined by the
maximum frequency that your FFT gives you. So the FFT-- again, if the
sampling rate is F double prime

in the FFT-- if this is frequency-- remember that FFTs are periodic,
with a period of the sampling

rate. And here, because
our angle of arrival can be positive or negative,
the period that we choose--

we choose to go from
minus the sampling rate, F double prime over 2,
to F double prime over 2.

So this is the
period that we look at when it comes to finding
the angle of arrival.

Anything outside this, we ignore
because it's just a repetition of this first period.

OK, so if you restrict
your search to that, the maximum angle
that you can find is basically half
your sampling rate.

OK, so your F theta max is
just F double prime S over 2. And then your angle becomes
arcsine of lambda times that.

And as I just said,
what is F double prime? That's 1 over D. That's
1 over the spacing between your antennas.

So your theta max becomes
arcsine of lambda over 2 D.

Here's another--
again, math is math, but the insight here is to
improve your field of view,

meaning to increase theta max-- your field of view is
technically 2 times theta max,

because you go from
both plus and minus. So it's from minus
absolute value of theta max to plus absolute
value of theta max.

So FOV is 2 times that. And to increase that, the
main thing that you can change

in this is this D. So if
you make your D smaller, if you place your
antennas more closely,

that improves your field
of view, basically. Because of this, the
most common choice for D

is half a wavelength. Because if you choose your D to
be lambda over 2, what happens is that your theta max becomes
arcsine of lambda over lambda,

which is arcsine of
1, so you basically get the full 180
degree field of view.

And that's as good as
it gets, basically. So most common ULA--

99% of radar arrays
you see out there, if you just open them up
and look at the antenna,

you would see a lambda over
2 Uniform Linear Array. And that's exactly
because of this.

And, again, this should
make sense exactly as when you talk about
time series signals,

if you want to be able to
see higher frequencies, you need to sample them
more finely in time.

Here, if you want
to see larger DOAs, we need to sample the
phase more finely in space.

So you need a more
tightly packed antenna array with a smaller D to be
able to see larger frequencies.

And larger frequencies
in this case mean larger
directions of arrival.

Now what happens if your D
is larger than lambda over 2, such that your theta max is--

I'm just going to make up
a number, as an example. So if your theta max-- this is a thought experiment.

We have an array with
some D, and the theta max comes out to be 50 degrees.

So the full field of view is
2 times that 100 degrees FOV-- FOV, 100 degrees.

And now I take that
radar out in the field. What happens to the targets that
are outside this field of view?

Like, if I have a target
at 130 degrees, which is a very strong reflector,
like a corner reflector,

what would happen? Do we not see anything
in our process data cube? Do we see something?
What do you think will happen?  Anyone?

The reflector [INAUDIBLE]
you'd see a smaller angle at something like [INAUDIBLE].

That's correct, so we
will see something. So let's see what will happen. So here, if you look at
our DOA FFT in this case,

we said we are going to look
from minus F double prime S over 2 to F double
prime S over 2.

Now in terms of angles,
we said that in this case, this corresponds to
50 degrees, and this

is negative 50 degrees,
the theta that correspond to those frequencies. Now, again, FFTs are periodic.

So as the angle DOA of
the target is increasing,

let's say on the positive side--
so there's going to be like a peak, and it's going to get
closer and closer to that 50

degrees, as it crosses-- let
me use a different color-- as it crosses our 50 degree--

so if I have a target that
is physically at 70 degrees-- remember, we are always
looking at this first period.

So what happens is that
we'll see the alias peak from the previous period that
is now showing at a very small--

a very large negative angle. So you will see
something, but it shows up

at the wrong DOA for you. And that's called wrapping. Again, there's this
periodic signal,

and things don't disappear,
they just wrap around. FFTs are periodic.

So that's a big problem. So very important. It's not like if
you design something

and you found a
FOV of 100 degrees, you're fine-- anything that's
outside 100 degrees just

doesn't show up. No, they actually will show
up, and they will completely mess up your radar image
because they wrap around

and show at the wrong DOA. Things don't
disappear, they just wrap around-- very important.

And again, that's
another reason why the safe choice is to go
with D that is lambda over 2.

Then you cover the
full 180 degrees. Stuff that's behind you,
you don't even physically hit them with your chirp.

So everything that's
in front of you, then you know that
things don't wrap around and that's your
safe bet, basically.

If you want to design a radar
that physically does not see outside, say 100
degrees, the only option

you have is to design antennas
with radiation patterns that are contained in 100 degrees.

And then, physically you don't
radiate outside that cone. And then you're
guaranteed to not

see targets that are
outside that field of view. Then you can place
them at a lambda--

bigger than lambda
over 2 spacing. Make sense? Did I clarify your question
about the F double prime?
OK, good. OK, so let's see--

so that's about
the DOA resolution and the maximum field
of view that you

can get with this algorithm. Now again, I want to
again reemphasize the fact

that first of all,
exactly every DSP

step that we develop
for the FMCW radar-- range estimation, velocity
estimation, and now, finally,

angle estimation, these all
turned out to be spectral estimation . Problems and the FFT
algorithm, again, it's

the simplest, most
efficient thing you can do. But in terms of
performance, it is not the best performing algorithm.

That's very, very
important to note. And that means there is huge
opportunity in the DSP domain

to improve the performance
of these types of radars. Now, specifically for the DBF--

the DBF method we developed,
the digital beamforming that is FFTs, it's even more limited
because of another fact,

which is that algorithm
is only compatible with uniform linear arrays. There are more
general algorithms.

Actually, in your homework, you
will develop a better algorithm that works for any
array, not just ULA,

and you would see
how that works. It's just an extension of
our FFT algorithm, basically.

Now when it comes
to DOA specifically, a lot of research
efforts have been spent

on better algorithms on radar. Because usually, the
resolution that you

get from FFTs for range
and velocity estimation is considered good enough for
most robotic applications.

But the resolution you get
from the FFT for the DOA is really not that great.

And especially we
just saw that it even degrades towards large angles. So it's very limited.

So a lot of the
research efforts have been, in the
algorithm space, have

been focused on super
resolution DOA methods. So if you look at
the literature, there's tons and tons of
interesting algorithms

that people have
tried successfully to improve the resolution,
DOA resolution of radars.

Roughly, you can categorize them
into three types of algorithms.

There's quadratic
methods, like Capon. There's subspace techniques--
these are very linear algebra

based and statistics based
methods, like MUSIC and ESPRIT And there is more modern
compressive sensing techniques,

like the iterative adaptive
approach or the Orthogonal Matching Pursuit, OMP.

Very, very rich, interesting,
active research area

for those of you who are
interested in radar DSP. And this still has a lot
of room for improvement.

We are not nearly there
when it comes to really modern interesting radar DSP.

So they're-- say,

And in the y-axis,

And in the x-axis-- in the z-axis,

And then everything works,

OK, so, just going to skip here.

And next topic is this idea
of waveform orthogonality

for MIMO radar. So when we developed this
concept of virtual array,

there was a implicit
assumption in there, which is extremely
important, but we

didn't talk about it until now. Which was the fact that
in our DOA processing,

we assumed that the
signals transmitted by different
transmitter antennas

are completely separable. And by separable,
I mean basically,

the IF signals,
which we called SIF of KQ, which correspond
to transmitter number K

and receiver number Q, all of
those we assume that they're individually, without
interference, accessible

to our DSP pipeline. And we just basically
called every KQ combination

a virtual antenna, and then we
work with the virtual array.

So that's a very
important assumption. Because, for instance, if
all the transmitters are

transmitting at the same
time, at the same frequency, the same waveform, there's no
way the receivers can separate

out which waveform
that they received was coming from
which transmitter.

So for this separability
assumption to hold, which is the underlying
assumption of basically

all of our MIMO
DSP, essentially we need to have orthogonality
between the signals

that different
transmitters transmit. And, again, by orthogonality,
I mean perfectly separable.

There is no overlap
or interference between different transmitters.

When it comes to
orthogonality, there's different ways you can
add that to the signals.

So there's essentially
three main techniques to orthogonalize the way the--

the transmitter is
in a MIMO system. The first one is time
division multiplexing,

or TDM, which is the
simplest thing you can do. Basically, you don't-- you
don't run all your transmits

at the same time. You sequence them. So transmit number
one sends everything-- all other transmitters
are silent.

And number two sends its chirp. Then number three sends
a chirp and so on. And then you repeat.

So that's the concept of TDM. You can also do
frequency division multiplexing if the
signals that are

sent by different transmitters,
the center frequency is different enough that they
don't overlap in frequency.

So the TDM makes sure they
don't overlap in time. FDM, or frequency
division multiplexing,

makes sure they're
separable in frequency. And the third one, which is
code division multiplexing,

basically uses
special waveforms, such that the
waveforms themselves are orthogonal and separable.

One example, we have seen is,
for instance, M sequences. We know that the cross
correlations of different M

sequences is almost zero. So they are separable,
exactly as GPS does.

GPS receivers can
separate out signals that they receive from
different satellites.

So to ensure, again,
separability, we need to orthogonalize
the signals.

You either do it in time,
in frequency, or in code. Those are the three,
basically, standard techniques.

Most common one that is done
today for FMCW MIMO is TDM.

And that's the one I'll
talk a little more about. FDM and CDM are not
used much today.

I hope we'll see more of
them, mostly because they add complexity to the hardware.

But TDM is just--
hardware's the same, it just makes your DSP
a little more involved.

So that's the main reason. But in terms of
performance, FDM and TDM can achieve better
performance than TDM.

So what is the TDM
MIMO principle? So the TDM MIMO principle,
again, very simple.

We can just look at this picture
here to fully understand it. So one frame of a
TDM MIMO waveform,

essentially, is broken into-- remember for the
case of SISO system,

we had M chirps in a frame. Now we have M-- what
we call chirp loops.

From zero to M minus 1. And what happens
inside every chirp loop is exactly as I said, all
the transmitters sequentially

transmit. So first, your TX1
sends the chirp. Every other TX is silent.

Then your TX2 sends a chirp. Then your TX3 sends a chirp. Then you're-- all
the way to the TXn.

And then you go to the
next chirp loop and repeat. So the overall waveform that you
get in TDM MIMO is like this.

So I'm using different colors
for different transmitters. And as you see, they are
completely separable in time.

So every receiver antenna,
when they receive an echo, they know exactly
which transmitter

it corresponds to because
only one transmitter was active at that time. So TDM, basically, it's kind
of trivial to separate out

the signals and then
construct your virtual array. However, as everything else,
there is no free lunch.

So it comes with a
couple of tradeoffs. First one is, of course it
makes your frame time longer.

Because now we are
at time multiplexing between different T axes. So to send the same
number of chirps--

so to keep this M
constant, same number of chips per transmit
antenna, if you do TDM,

now your frame takes a
factor of NTx longer. So if you have 10 Tx's,
and you TDM MIMO them,

then your frame time
becomes 10 times longer, which means your frame rate
is dropping by a factor of 10.

So that's the first tradeoff. Everything becomes slower
because you're sharing time. OK, but it has even more
important consequences.

And the main one that
basically becomes

a big limitation of TDM MIMO
is, if you look at this picture

here-- remember, when we are looking
at the data cube of our radar,

we have different
sampling rates. So you have your
ADC sampling rate. That's your fast time axis.

Those are like the rows
of the raw data cube. And then you have your slow
time, which if you remember,

the sampling rate is the time
between two consecutive chirps

that are transmitted from
the same transmitter. So if you look at your green
transmitter, one sample here

and one sample here, now
that is our new slow time

sampling interval. So if we do TDM
MIMO, our slow time

is going to become a
factor of NTx slower. So the sampling rate
in the Doppler axis

is going to drop
by a factor of NTx. What does that mean? If you remember the Doppler
resolution and maximum

velocity equations
that we developed, the maximum Doppler frequency
that you can detect,

because it's tied to the FFT,
is proportional to, basically,

the inverse of your slow
time, which is the sampling rate across the Doppler axis.

The sampling rate drops, which
means maximum frequency drops. So the maximum velocity
that you can detect

drops by a factor of
NTx in TDM MIMO case. This can be-- depending
on your application,

you might not care about it. If that maximum velocity
is still acceptable, you're like, OK, fine.,
I'll just live with it.

But in certain
applications, this might be a block here already. So say, in autonomous
driving, originally you

designed your frame and chirp
waveform parameters such that the maximum
detectable velocity

was 100 miles per hour. And now you TDM MIMO it
with 10 transmitters.

Your sampling rate
across Doppler drops by a factor of 10, which
means your maximum Doppler

velocity drops by
a factor of 10. Now from 100 miles
per hour, you're down to 10 miles per hour.

That's absolutely not acceptable
for autonomous driving. Everything pretty
much on the roads

is moving faster than
10 miles per hour. So that can become a big issue.

So, again, here's the math. Your maximum
detectable velocity-- originally, if you remember,
it was lambda over 4 times

T, where T was the
chirp duration.

That was for the case
of a SISO system. Now for a TDM MIMO system, it
becomes lambda over 4 times T

loop, where T loop is the loop
time, which is and n number of Tx times the chirp time.

So your maximum velocity again
is dropping by a factor of NTx compared to the
size of SISO case.

Can be a huge problem. What can you do about it? It turns out there is
a number of techniques.

This is, again, one of
those very active research areas for radar, but there's
a number of techniques that you can use to
essentially increase back

the maximum velocity
you can detect. Very briefly, what
you can do, you

can either design special
antenna arrays that help you recover a larger--

or unwrap your velocity FFT
and recover larger velocities. You can design special
waveforms that,

again, enable you to
recover large velocities in the case of TDM MIMO.

Or you can basically design
better DSP algorithms. So instead of just
doing an FFT, you

do something more
sophisticated, which doesn't have the limitations
associated with FFT. And a big limitation
associated with FFT

is, again, the maximum
velocity you can detect is tied to the sampling rate.

But there are other algorithms,
which don't operate that way. And then they can
recover large velocities

in the case of TDM MIMO. So, again, TDM MIMO,
very easy technique

to basically give you
separability or orthogonality between the transmitted
waveforms in the case of MIMO.

But this is the first
limitation of it. It has a second-- I wouldn't call it a
limitation, but a caveat that--

it actually is not highlighted
enough in literature, and oftentimes, people miss it.

And the system still
works with significantly degraded performance. So I just want to
highlight that here.

That is called
phase from motion. So what the second
thing is, is--

very briefly, if we look
at one of these chirp loops that we do in a TDM MIMO
configuration-- again,

remember that your transmitters
are going sequentially. Your TX1 fires. then TX2 fires,
and TX3 fires, all the way

to TXn. And if we look at our
original signal model

it has two components. It has this temporal
component, SIF of T. And it has this spatial phase,
which is E to the J omega IP.

And we basically work
with this E to the J omega I to recover
direction of arrival.

Now for TDM MIMO,
there is a third term in the phase term in
the signal model, which

we call the TDM phase. And that is added
because of the fact

that your chips are not
sent at the same time from different transmitters. So each transmit
index K, because it

starts at a different
point in time, the phase that you
receive from that is going to be different
from different transmitters.

And that is this third term,
which is E to the minus J2pi. FD is the Doppler frequency.

K is the index of the
transmitter antenna, not the virtual antenna, bu the
physical transmitter antenna.

So it goes from 1
to NTx times big T, which is the chirp duration. So that's basically T.

So more concretely, at the
start of every chip loop, you can assume that term is--

there's no phase for
your first transmitter, but your second transmitter,
because it starts t seconds

later, there's this additional
phase, E to the minus J2pi FDT. Your third transmitter
has a phase E

to the minus J2pi FD
times 2t, and so on. If you don't-- if
I clean this up--

if you don't model this
term and compensate for it, it's just going to effectively
corrupt your omega KQ phase.

And that means it's going to
degrade your DOA estimation.

But it's extremely easy
to compensate for this. Because after we do our
range and Doppler processing,

essentially we know
this TDM phase term. Because we have found FD
for every processed cell

in the data cube. And K is just a transmitter
index, which is known. And for every slice
of the data cube.

And big T is, again,
the trip duration. So this entire TDM
phase term is known.

And all you need
to do to compensate for want to know who's after you
do your range and Doppler FFTs,

you did this
additional step, which we are multiplying by E to
the J minus that TDM phase

to cancel it out. And per cell, you
multiply by this term, it cancels out the TDM phase,
and then you do your DOA FFT.

you're going to significantly
degrade the DOA performance. Here's one example.

This is very simple scene,
just one target in this scene.

And this is the point
cloud, if you will-- 2D point cloud. Also, you can think of
it as a range azimuth
map of the target. So that's basically the target.

That's what you get if you do
proper TDM phase compensation. If you forget that
step multiplying

by the inverse of the TDM
phase, it still kind of, sort of

works. You do get a point cloud. But look how much blurred this
is compared to-- it's blurred.

It's also not exactly
at the right DOA. So if you compare this angle
theta with this angle theta,

you would see,
they're not the same. There's a little bit of
rotation because, again, you have affected the phase.

Extremely, again,
important-- do not forget this if you're working
with a TDM MIMO system.

And I've seen textbooks
that entirely miss this. They don't even mention that
this is a critical step.

And nobody knows, because
it kind of, sort of works, it's just not as good
as it could possibly be.

Questions?  OK, so, again, this was one
way of ensuring separability

of the transmitted
signals, using the time division multiplexing concept. There's frequency division
and code division multiplexing
that I'm not going to-- I'm not going to go over them.

Because most the standard
hardware's don't support them anyway. But I hope we see more of them.

The math and the
explanations are in the notes if you're interested.

OK, so we're going to basically
close the radar chapter just with a few remarks.

Radar, again, it's
extremely useful. And there's a lot
you can do with it.

antenna design, algorithms,
waveform design-- and by algorithm,
I mean ranging,

Doppler, target
detection, direction of arrival-- across
the board, any point

that you put your
finger on, it still has a ton of room
for improvement. So I really believe in
the next 10, 15, 20 years,

you're going to see
significant improvement in what radars can do.

And as part of that,
there is a number of challenges that
I want to highlight, that need to be
basically figured out.

And they're actively
being researched on. One is the multipath effect. So multipath effect,
essentially what it is,

is that if you have big
flat surfaces in the scene,

your millimeter wave
emissions can basically

bounce off of them,
kind of like they can act like mirrors almost. So here if you have a radar
on this blue car, Ego vehicle,

and the red is like the target
in front of it, of course, you would have
this direct travel

path of the millimeter wave. And that gives you
the real target. But if it's driving on a road,
and you have metal guardrails

on the side, it can happen that
you actually hit the guardrail

and you get reflected,
hit the target, and then you take
the same path back.

And if you do your standard
DSP on this, of course, the receiver DSP doesn't
know that this echo that it

received was from a multipath. So it just processes it,
and it finds range and DOA.

And in your point
cloud, it would show as a target that was
there, which is a ghost target.

It's at the wrong DOA
and at the wrong range. And it's not even
a physical target.

So that can be a big problem. Again, it depends on your
application, the environment that you're operating at.

If there's-- especially
like indoors, it's horrible. Like in this room, if you
were to operate radar,

the ceiling, the
floor, all the walls would create a lot
of multipath echoes, so we would see a ton of
ghost targets, for instance.

And, again, there's
different ways. It's a very active
research area, how you essentially detect
and eliminate multipath.

People have gotten
very promising results. And you can do-- especially
again, antenna design, waveform design, or DSP.

The other effect is
mutual interference. So if you have two
radars on two robots

or two cars-- so let's say, the
red car here has its own radar and the blue has its
own radar, and they're

pointing at each other,
and the two radars are operating at the same
frequency at the same time,

and sending the same
kind of waveforms, then they can
interfere, essentially like blind each other.

Or even if not
fully blinding, it can significantly raise the
noise floor, for instance,

because of a lot of
inbound interference. So that can be a big problem. This is one of the areas where
PMCW radar really shines.

Because, again, as we know,
these ranging codes that are used in PMCW, the M
sequences, all you need to do

is use two different
M sequences, and then they're orthogonal,
and they wouldn't interfere.

FMCW, really that's-- is
not that good in this area.

FMCW is kind of like analog
waveforms that you're sending, so they can really interfere
with each other a lot.

And, again, it's a very
active research area. People have come up with
very clever algorithms

to essentially mitigate
this mutual interference.

And the third one is a physical
effect called spillover.

And a spillover is
basically direct coupling from a transmitter
antenna to a receiver,

antenna without
echoing from a target. So if your antennas have
very wide radiation patterns,

and if transmitter and receiver
antennas are placed closely, which can happen on these
micro strip antennas,

signal can directly
spill, basically, from the transmitter
to the receiver.

And then two things happen. One is, because
it's very strong-- it's right next to the
transmitter, so you

get a very strong
coupling, and you eat into the dynamic
range of your receiver.

But also, if you process
it, it might even show up as a target
at a very close range.

That could also happen. Sometimes some receivers apply
what is called range gating.

So they just ignore
anything that is too close. And they say, this is
probably spillover.

If it's less than
a couple of inches, they don't even show
it or process it.

But still, it can eat
into the dynamic range. And best thing you can do is, if
you're involved in the antenna

design process, is to,
in simulations, check for how much coupling you
get between transmitter

and receiver antennas, and
ensure by design, by adding sufficient isolation and
spacing between the antennas,

ensure that this doesn't
become a big problem. OK?

I have a question. Yes. What's an example of adding
isolation, other than putting

them further apart? So it depends on what
kind-- the question is, what is an example
of adding isolation aside

from just adding space? It depends on the

micro strip antennas,

like these little patch
antennas on a PCB, if possible,

one thing you can do is
add ground in between. So let's say--

I ran out of space. Let me sketch it again. So if this is a transmitter
antenna and micro strip

on a PCB, if you add a bit of
just ground copper between that

and a receiver antenna,
that can add isolation.

But, again, there
is no free lunch. Because if you add
this ground, it will also affect the radiation
pattern or the gain pattern
of the antenna. Everything is a tradeoff. So yes, you can add ground.

If you add it too close, you
reduce your coupling a lot, but you also affect the
radiation pattern a lot.

And then that can add
extra complications. But it's a technique. It is used. When you can, you add grounding
to basically help shape it.

The best thing is just a space,
like as much as possible, don't place them too
close to each other.

Yeah. If you remember--
or maybe later, you can check on your slides-- there

If you look at that, all

so basically collimate

And then based on the light

concept of the searchlight

that was proposed in the '30s. And then about the
same time, Lebedev

proposed the idea
of instead of just shining a beam of
light, what about

sending short pulses of flight. And again, this
is pre-laser days. But if you send
short pulses, and

look at the reflected
echoes of those pulses-- and here, by echo, this is
optical echo, of course--

you can measure
the time of flight. So he basically
proposed the idea

of time of flight
measurement using optics.

A few years later, in 1936,
some very successful experiments were done. Again, this was done
with visible light,

but people could measure
ranges up to 3.5 kilometers with very decent
accuracy, 2 to 3 meters,

using this idea of short-- send a short pulse of light,
and then collect back the echo,

and measure, basically,
range from time of flight. Then fast forward
20-something years.

In 1960, the first
laser was invented. And then soon after that, people
put the two ideas together.

So lasers, what
they're really good for is making very short pulses.

And you can also collimate
them, as we'll see, very easily. So you can make very
narrow beams of lasers,

and also you can send
very short pulses. So people started--
almost immediately

after the laser was invented,
the first applications, people were thinking
of laser rangefinders.

So rangefinder is like a
very, very simple LiDAR, where it doesn't give you a full map. It just measures the
range to one point,

from this time of
flight measurement. And a few years later, I mean
in early-- from the early '60s,

even commercial
laser rangefinders started hitting the market. The first one was from the
Hughes Aircraft Company.

Very soon after that, actually,
Stanford got into the game-- the Stanford Research
Institute here in Palo Alto.

They started doing the
first LiDAR experiments. Again, these were not 2023 LiDAR
that gives you a nice 3D point

cloud. These were just
laser rangefinders. But people were--
essentially the core concept

and the physics is the same. And then the Swedish
army got into the game.

The Soviet Union
started, basically, building rangefinders. And especially for
military applications,

and also for meteorology,
it started, basically,

becoming commercialized. And then it was a little later,
in the '70s and the '80s where

more applications of these-- still rangefinders, but
you can think of as early--

early LiDARs-- more
applications started becoming basically common.

Wind measurement, missile
guidance in the military,

mapping of the polar
ice caps, for instance, and police speed guns were
using basically pulses

of short pulses of laser and
the early LiDAR concepts.

But it was only at the 1990s
where the modern-day imaging

LiDARs, which give you these
very nice, high-resolution 3D point clouds started
to become commercial.

So in comparison, imaging
LiDARs are a much modern--

although, again, the core idea
was thought of in the '30s,

it wasn't until the '90s
that the technology maturity was at the level that
these modern-day imaging

LiDARs could be developed. And at that sense, it's a much
younger technology, compared

to, say, radar, or
sonar, or other things we have talked about.

So here are some pictures. These are from the 1930s,
the early rangefinder LiDARs.

So this is the
SRI MARK I LiDAR-- SRI is again Stanford
Research Institute.

So this might be somewhere
in Palo Alto, actually, this picture. And, again, there's--
these are huge systems.

And there's a transmitter
and a receiver. So one sends the pulse, the
other one received the pulse. And then there's a lot of
equipment to control the laser

and also process to received
echo to measure range. So this would just give
you one range measurement.

This is SRI MARK II. And this is the one that
the Howard Hughes Aircraft

Company made. It kind of looks like
a rifle, interestingly. And it's called the
Hughes Collider MARK

II, was the marketing
term that they were using. It was like a portable,
basically, rangefinder thing.

Here, I have a
modern rangefinder. You might have seen these.

Let's actually power it on
and take a look at together. Again, it does the
exact same thing.

So this is not a LiDAR. It's just a rangefinder--
if I can turn it on.

OK. So this one, it comes
with a red laser pointer.

So this is-- the red
is just-- a red laser, they don't use it for ranging. It's just for aiming, so I
know where I'm pointing at.

And then if I hit
it, then it gives me the distance, 8.65 meters.

So, again, this is not
a LiDAR, but you see-- because if you can
do this, you can also

make a LiDAR-- if you
do this fast enough, and you scan your beam, and
you do one range measurement

per position, and then for
each range measurement, I also know where
I'm pointing at.

So the DOA is kind
of trivial for LiDAR. Because the beam is
so focused, I just need to know where I'm
physically pointing it to.

I don't need to do complex DSP. And you just scan it and do a
bunch of range measurements.

And then you build,
basically, a 3D map. And that's how
essentially LiDAR works.

So you can kind of see
from here that the DSP is going to be much more simple
than radar, for instance.

Because part of the complication
of the DSP for radar is the fact that,
especially for MIMO radar,

with micro strip antennas, you
have very wide beam patterns. So you receive echoes from
everything in the scene

at a very wide field of view. And then you have to untangle
everything, and figure out the range of every target,
the DOA of every target,

and the velocity of
every target in DSP. Versus in LiDAR, you pretty
much can assume the signal

that you receive at
any point in time is coming from just one target. Because your beam is so focused,
it's just millimeters wide,

and it's very, very
low [INAUDIBLE].. So this is the '30s. Now fast forward to 2020s.

Now, of course, we have
much, much better LiDARs. You can get very high-resolution
3D maps from them,

like this one from
Stanford campus. And they're used in many
different applications--

oceanography, meteorology. Even some cellphones these days
have built-in little LiDARs

that are used for
AR/VR applications. And, of course, in
autonomy, especially in self-driving or
autonomous vehicles,

LiDARs are one of the key
enabling, basically, sensors.

OK, so LiDAR physics-- very briefly, again,
as I just showed you

with the rangefinder, the
principle of operation is extremely simple. You have a laser source.

So it generates a laser for you. It goes through TX optics. And by optics, I
mean just lenses.

What the lenses
do, as we'll see, it will basically make this
nice collimated narrow beam

of laser for you that
doesn't diverge too quickly. So then you get this pencil beam
that goes and hits a target.

And then you get this
part of the light echoed back or reflected back.

And then on the
receive side, you also have some optics or lenses. And then the optics basically
focuses the received light

echo into a photodetector. And from the photodetector, we
get some signal waveform out

that we can pass to our DSP. And then, basically, estimate
range and possibly velocity.

So, again, exact same
principle of operation as radar and sonar,
but operating

at different wavelengths. And because of that, it comes
with very different performance metrics.

You also want to basically
scan your transmitter beam. As I said, you want
to keep aiming it

at different locations. And you want to
do this very fast. LiDARs today, good
ones, can give you

multiple million
measurements per second. Like 2 to 5 million
points per second,

basically, is what modern
day lighters operate at.

So, basically, are
going to study this starting from the physics. We'll look at laser
physics first.

Then we talk about
these beams, which are called Gaussian
beams, and how they're generated, how they behave.

We talk about the
optics, which basically collimate the beam for you. And then we talk about the
principles of photodetection.

What is a photodetector? How does it work? What is the physics of it? And then once we do
that, we basically

can complete our
system architecture. And then we build a
signal model for ST.

And finally, we talk about
the DSP, exact same story as we did for radar and sonar.

I think this is a
good place to stop. And then we will
continue next time.
